title: R44392
content: The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) covers 72.5% of the premium for eligible taxpayers, who are responsible for the remaining 27.5%. It can be used towards qualified health insurance and is refundable and advanceable. Eligibility is based on receiving certain benefits under the Trade Adjustment Assistance program or being between 55 and 64 receiving payments from the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation. The Trade Adjustment Assistance (TAA) program provides assistance to workers who lose their jobs due to international trade. Workers aged 55-64 receiving payments from the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation can qualify for TAA benefits. Eligibility for the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) is based on receiving certain TAA benefits like Trade Readjustment Allowance (TRA) or Reemployment Trade Adjustment Assistance (RTAA). Workers aged 50 and older who were certified for TAA can receive Reemployment Trade Adjustment Assistance (RTAA) which pays 50% of the wage difference for up to two years. Alternative Trade Adjustment Assistance (ATAA) is a similar wage-insurance program. Eligibility for the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) is limited to individuals receiving TRA, RTAA, or ATAA cash benefits. To receive Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation (PBGC) benefits, individuals must have worked for a firm with an insured defined-benefit pension plan taken over by the PBGC. Workers aged 50 and older certified for TAA can receive RTAA or ATAA benefits. To receive PBGC benefits, individuals must have worked for a firm with an insured defined-benefit pension plan taken over by the PBGC. Those receiving PBGC-paid pensions are eligible for HCTC if at least 55 years old and not yet entitled to Medicare. HCTC has limitations on eligibility, excluding those enrolled in certain health plans. The HCTC program has limitations on eligibility, excluding those enrolled in specific health plans, Medicare Part B, FEHBP, Medicaid, CHIP, Medicare Part A, Tricare, incarcerated individuals, and those who can be claimed as a dependent. Eligible taxpayers can use the HCTC for health insurance covering their spouse and dependents. Children of divorced or separated parents are considered dependents of the custodial parent. Qualifying family members face the same eligibility restrictions as eligible individuals. The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) program allows eligible taxpayers to claim the credit to cover part of the premium for qualified health insurance. Qualifying family members, including spouses and dependents, can receive the HCTC for up to two years under certain circumstances. The qualified health insurance is limited to 11 categories of coverage, with four options being automatically qualified health plans. One of these options includes coverage under COBRA. Automatically qualified health plans, known by statutory letter designations, can be elected without state involvement. These options include coverage under COBRA, a spouse's group health plan, individual health insurance, and coverage funded by a VEBA. State-qualified health plans, established by states, offer categories such as state-based continuation coverage, coverage through a state high-risk pool, and coverage under a state-based plan comparable to state employee plans. State-qualified health plans must provide four consumer protections to qualifying individuals, including guaranteed issue, coverage for preexisting conditions, and equal premiums for all qualifying applicants. These plans are available to HCTC-eligible individuals with prior creditable coverage and no significant breaks in coverage. The HCTC program requires state-qualified health plans to offer certain protections, including guaranteed issue, coverage for preexisting conditions, equal premiums for all qualifying individuals, and similar benefits. Certain types of coverage are not considered qualified health insurance under the program. The IRS administers the HCTC program, with involvement from various federal and state agencies. The HCTC program involves multiple federal and state agencies in its administration. The Department of the Treasury handles the advance payment system, while the IRS reviews tax returns for the credit. DOL and PBGC assist in identifying eligible individuals, and state entities like SWAs and health agencies play a role in providing information and eligibility certificates to potential beneficiaries. The HCTC program involves various federal and state agencies in its administration. SWAs and PBGC identify eligible individuals and provide their information to the IRS. Eligible taxpayers with qualified health insurance can claim the tax credit when filing their tax returns or receive advance payments monthly. The HCTC is refundable, allowing taxpayers to receive the full amount they are eligible for, regardless of their tax liability. The HCTC program allows eligible taxpayers to claim the full credit amount, regardless of their tax liability. Claiming the HCTC does not affect eligibility for other tax credits, except for the premium tax credit under the Affordable Care Act. IRS data shows that in 2013, 13,693 tax returns claimed the HCTC, totaling $52.3 million. Taxpayers must file Form 8885 with proof of payment for qualified health insurance to claim the refundable credit. Taxpayers claiming the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) must include invoices and proof of payment for qualified health insurance on their Form 1040. The credit amount reduces taxes owed and is refundable if it exceeds the tax amount. To receive advance payments, individuals enroll in the HCTC program, pay their share of the premium, and Treasury covers the rest to the health insurance plans.
